taskbody.prereq: You may start this stage once you have received an approval to buy a TMS from your management.

step.cmd: Start the sales process with TMS provider (either through your purchasing department or on your own):

substep.cmd: Ask for all necessary agreements (subscription agreement, NDA, SLA, DPA if applicable).
Consult these documents with your legal department. Allocate some time for this part because the negotiation process is usually a lengthy one.
Request an offer to be presented to the management for final approval (containing all the terms and conditons of purchase).
Arrange for a TMS to be installed on-premises or on your instance in the cloud.

step.cmd: Train your team, translation vendors and other internal customers that need to work with it. You need some time to implement it and learn how to use it.

substep.cmd: Prepare internal documentation for your new TMS to present its main features and benefits of using it.
Manage the whole onboarding process by delivering training to new users (project managers, reviewers, translators).
Draft relevant documentation (e.g. checklist for translation vendors, guide on how to review documents).
Set yourself as the first point of contact for all TMS-related issues (user access rights, technical support).
Carry out an internal marketing campaign for your refreshed translation process with your TMS as the key tool. Advertise it e.g. in the intranet.
Start looking for new partners if not all of your translation vendors wish to continue cooperation with you with the use of the new TMS.

step.cmd: Migrate all your TMs and TBs (if any) to the TMS. Create workflows, user accounts with relevant access rights and roles.

Start working with your new TMS, initially only for some projects (the easiest ones) and gradually move the whole translation process to it. Once you discover all the TMS’s features, you will no longer imagine work outside it ;). You will process even very complex projects in it.

Be prepared to report on TMS key metrics such as translation volume (number of TM segments, translated words), language pairs, discounts on TM use, overall external costs. It is a good idea to have an Excel report at hand with all relevant data generated from TMS from time to time. Every management would like to be updated on the metrics (KPIs) relating to the process.
Once in a while, review your decision:

substep.cmd: Check if the TMS meets your business needs: are there more advantages than disadvantages from using it? Are all of your company’s requirements met?
Continue taking part in webinars to be up-to-date with your TMS upgrades.
Check what is available in the market: has anything new appeared or changed in the TMS offer?
Ask yourself a question if you are satisfied with cooperation with this TMS provider (e.g. as regards IT support, your customer success manager).
